text.p: The following Australian economic indicators and events are scheduled for this week.
DAY GMT Indicator Period Forecast Previous
Wed 0130 Westpac Consumer sent Oct n/f -1.2 pct
Wed/Thu 0500 RBA Bulletin - including quarterly econ review
Thu 0130 Manufact input prices Aug n/f -1.3 pct
Thu 0130 Export price index Aug n/f -0.1 pct
Thu 0130 Import price index Aug n/f -0.3 pct
Fri 0130 Merchandise Imports Sep +1.0 pct +1.1 pct
Tue 0900 RBA Governor Ian Macfarlane speaks at Leura, NSW
Wed 0130 Underlying inflation Q3 +0.6 pct +0.8 pct
Wed 0430 Westpac Leading index Aug +1.7 pct
Wed 0830 Treasury Secretary Ted Evans speaks in Melbourne
Fri 0130 New Motor Registrations Sep +6.9 pct

QUESTION OF THE WEEK - The final ingredients for the widely expected November rate cut are seen as third quarter inflation and wages data due October 23 and 24 respectively, so economists were asked for their forecasts of the quarterly movements.

These forecasts will be finalised over the coming week, but they do show that in annual terms the consumer price index, underlying inflation and the average weekly ordinary time earnings (AWOTE) measure of wages are all seen moderating further from their levels at the end of the June quarter.
The median forecasts translate to an annual change in the CPI of 2.3 percent, an underlying rate of 2.5 percent and an AWOTE increase of 3.7 percent.

In annualised terms the quarterly change in the underlying rate is seen falling within the two to three percent target band, and AWOTE is also seen coming in under the 4.5 percent level economists said was the maximum rate of increase seen as tolerable to the Reserve Bank.
As a result, economists said results in line with the median forecasts should be supportive of a rate cut.
Stronger than expected data, especially for wages, would not necessarily rule out a November rate cut, economists said.

MERCHANDISE IMPORTS - Imports have been weak in recent months and the median forecast suggests economists do not expect the series to show any signs of renewed strength just yet. Capital goods are seen as the key area in imports. Having fallen heavily in June and July, they rose in August due to the inclusion of an aircraft import. Some economists expected a small aircraft to be included in the September data. Continued softness in capital goods may raise concerns about the budget forecast of a 14 percent increase in business investment in 1996/97 and so the 3.25 percent economic growth forecast.
